assessments.task_description:
The rapid development of generative AI tools, including ChatGPT, has profoundly shaped how we work, communicate, and learn. In higher education—particularly in language learning—AI now provides instant, human-like interaction opportunities that were previously difficult to access. 

Task details:

1. Student-ChatGPT Interaction: Students will complete speaking practice with ChatGPT, using it as a native-like conversation partner. To ensure appropriate and ethical use of AI tools, students must submit (1 ) a video or screen recording of their interaction and (2) a written record or transcript of the ChatGPT conversation to Blackboard/Ultra. These submissions are due at 1pm every Monday, starting from Week 3 (except in Week 10 - Due to the Monday Public Holiday, the recording will be due 1pm Tuesday). A demonstration is provided during the Wednesday Tutorial in Week 1.

2.Teacher Feedback: The teacher will provide general feedback on both the students' spoken Chinese and ChatGPT’s output, and specific feedback to any individual student can be provided on request.

3.Critical Reflection: Students will write a reflection evaluating their experience with ChatGPT-assisted speaking practice, including a critical consideration of AI’s strengths and limitations and potential ways AI could be used in future language-learning contexts. The reflection needs to be submitted to Blackboard/Ultra by 5pm on Friday in Week 13.

  • Week 2 Topic: Self-introduction
  • Week 3 Topic: Seeing a doctor
  • Week 4 Topic: Dating
  • Week 5 Topic: Renting an apartment
  • Week 6 Topic: Sports
  • Week 7 Topic: Travel
  • Week 8 Topic: At the airport
  • Week 9 Topic: Starting a new semester
  • Week 10 Topic: Dorm life
  • Week 11 Topic: At a restaurant

Statement on the use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) 

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

This 90-minute, in-semester, in-person exam involves listening comprehension, filling in blanks, translation of sentences from English to Chinese, and creating dialogues, etc. 

The exam will be conducted in classroom using hardcopy exam papers.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
You can talk about anything related to the Chinese language and Culture. For example, you could describe your experience of learning Chinese, e.g. why you chose to study Chinese, what level you are at now, what fun/difficulties did you have in learning it, whether you will continue learning it, and how you hope to use these language skills in the future, and how will the language skills help you to realize your dreams, particularly how the learning of Chinese helps you form friendship with native speakers of Chinese or anyone else, how the learning of Chinese helps you become more open-minded and more understanding of the world we live in, etc.

Specific topics: 1. Why do I study Chinese; 2. My trip to China; 3. My Chinese friend; 4. I find the Chinese Culture fascinating; 5. My experiences in learning Chinese.  Choose one of the topics listed or self-nominate a topic that is related to the Chinese language and culture for your oral presentation. 

Text submission: You will need to submit the text in pinyin and/or characters before the time you give your talk. You can consult your language partner, but they will only give you assistance with grammar points and word usage you are unsure of. You are the one who will draft the speech, not anyone else. 

The following aids are permitted during presentation:

  1. One PPT slide is allowed, which is encouraged.
  2. Palm cards can be used for occasional assistance. You are not allowed to simply read from it. If you do, it will be considered a reading activity, not a presentation, and you will gain a maximum mark of 50% only (see marking criteria for details). 

Criteria & Marking:

An overall assessment will be made that takes into account all of the following aspects of the presentation. 

  • Accuracy of pronunciation and tones
  • Content 
  • Accuracy of grammar 
  • Fluency 
  • Presentation techniques (clear, loud voice, interaction with audience etc)
  • Originality/Flair 

STATEMENT ON AI & MT

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted in the oral venue. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. You may, however, find it useful to use these tools to plan and practice for your oral, for example, looking up vocabulary, checking pronunication; generating possible questions you might want to ask. Remember that this task is to show your oral ability in Chinese, NOT about performing a script.
